item.title: 001 Inor10uk-Q2 Which of the following ions has the smallest radius ?

material.mattext: Which of the following ions has the smallest radius ?
Ca2+
Cr3+
Na+
Ag+
O22-
Ions contract with increasing positive charge.
Ions contract with increasing positive charge.
Ions contract with increasing positive charge.
Ions contract with increasing positive charge.

item.title: 002 Inor11uk-Q2 Which of the following statements are true for a triple

material.mattext: Which of the following statements are true for a triple bond ?
It is stronger and longer than a double bond.
It is stronger and shorter than a double bond.
It is weaker and longer than a double bond.
It is weaker and shorter than a double bond.
It is stronger and shorter than a single bond.
Stronger bonds are shorter than corresponding weaker ones.Strength increases in the order: single, double, triple.

item.title: 003 Inor12uk-Q2 The molecule of BCl3, in it's equilibrium configuration

material.mattext:
The molecule of BCl3 , in its equilibrium configuration, is planar, with 120Â° between the bonds.
The symmetry elements possessed by this molecule are:

Where:
E = identity ; Cn = n-fold axis ; s = plane ;
Sn = improper axis order n ; h, v = horizontal, vertical.
E , 2C3 , 3C2 , sh , 3sv , 2S3
E , 2C2 , 3C3 , sh , 3sv , 2S3
E , 3C2 , 3C3 , sh , 3sv , 2S3
E , 2C2 , 3C3 , 3sh , sv , 2S3
E , 2C2 , 3C3 , sh , 3sv , S3

item.title: 004 Inor13uk-Q2 The compound K2[OsCl5N] has the systematic

Potassium pentachloronitridoosmate(VIII)
Potassium pentachloronitridoosmate(VI)
Potassium amidopentachloroosmate(VI)
Potassium azidopentachloroosmate(VI)
Potassium chlorohydrazidoosmate(V)
The ligands are 5 Cl- and a nitrido N3-.The metal oxidation state is in brackets after the anion.
The ligands are 5 Cl- and a nitrido N3-.The metal oxidation state is in brackets after the anion.
The ligands are 5 Cl- and a nitrido N3-.The metal oxidation state is in brackets after the anion.
The ligands are 5 Cl- and a nitrido N3-.The metal oxidation state is in brackets after the anion.

item.title: 005 Inor14uk-Q2 Which of the following stereochemistries are possible

material.mattext: Which of the following stereochemistries are possible for a metal complex of the general formula MX2Y2?
tetrahedral and square planar
tetrahedral and octahedral
square planar and octahedral
linear and tetrahedral
trigonal planar and tetrahedral

item.title: 006 Inor15uk-Q2 When hydrides of the alkali metals are treated

material.mattext: When hydrides of the alkali metals are treated with water, one of the final products will be:
H2
H-
H+
O2
There is no reaction
Equilibrium between H-, H+ and H2 lies effectively towards H2.Any solvent such as water which gives a concentration of protons [solvated] will therefore give dihydrogen.
Equilibrium between H-, H+ and H2 lies effectively towards H2.Any solvent such as water which gives a concentration of protons [solvated] will therefore give dihydrogen.
Equilibrium between H-, H+ and H2 lies effectively towards H2.Any solvent such as water which gives a concentration of protons [solvated] will therefore give dihydrogen.
Equilibrium between H-, H+ and H2 lies effectively towards H2.Any solvent such as water which gives a concentration of protons [solvated] will therefore give dihydrogen.

item.title: 007 inor16uk-Q2 When PBr5 is treated with water, the products

material.mattext: When PBr5 is treated with water, the products will be:
H3PO4 and HBr
H3PO3 and HBr
H3PO2 and HBr
H2P2O7 and HBr
P4O10 and Br2
No redox reactions occur, so H3PO3, H3PO2 and H2PO7 are wrong. P(V) oxide reacts with water.
No redox reactions occur, so H3PO3, H3PO2 and H2PO7 are wrong. P(V) oxide reacts with water.
No redox reactions occur, so H3PO3, H3PO2 and H2PO7 are wrong. P(V) oxide reacts with water.
No redox reactions occur, so H3PO3, H3PO2 and H2PO7 are wrong. P(V) oxide reacts with water.

item.title: 008 Inor17uk-Q2 Of the following statements about fluorine

material.mattext: Of the following statements about fluorine, which is not true?
It produces low oxidation states in the elements with which it reacts.
It has a high electronegativity.
It forms a series of compounds with the other halogens.
It is a small atom.
The F-F bond has a low enthalpy.
Fluorine generally brings out the highest oxidation states in the elements it reacts with.
Fluorine generally brings out the highest oxidation states in the elements it reacts with.
Fluorine generally brings out the highest oxidation states in the elements it reacts with.
Fluorine generally brings out the highest oxidation states in the elements it reacts with.

item.title: 009 Inor18uk-Q2 Of the following pairs of transition metals, which has atoms

material.mattext: Of the following pairs of transition metals, which has atoms of about the same metallic radius?
Zr and Hf
Cr and Mo
Ni and Pd
Ti and Ca
Ta and Ir

2nd & 3rd row transition metals have approximately similar radii from a combination of the increase from the 4d to 5d shells and the intervening lanthanide contraction. Zr & Hf are particularly close.

2nd & 3rd row transition metals have approximately similar radii from a combination of the increase from the 4d to 5d shells and the intervening lanthanide contraction. Zr & Hf are particularly close.

2nd & 3rd row transition metals have approximately similar radii from a combination of the increase from the 4d to 5d shells and the intervening lanthanide contraction. Zr & Hf are particularly close.

2nd & 3rd row transition metals have approximately similar radii from a combination of the increase from the 4d to 5d shells and the intervening lanthanide contraction. Zr & Hf are particularly close.

item.title: 010 Inor19uk-Q2 How many unpaired electrons would you expect to find in the cation

material.mattext:
How many unpaired electrons would you expect to find in the cation

[Co(NH3)6]2+?
Type your answer in the answer box:
The species is octahedral, d^7, with ligands exerting a small crystal field. The configuration will therefore be t_2g^5 . e_g#^2 ; giving 3 unpaired electrons (a high spin configuration).

item.title: 011 Inor1auk-Q2 For many ligand substitution reactions of octahedral complexes

material.mattext:
For many ligand substitution reactions of octahedral complexes, it has been found that the rate has little dependence on the nature of the incoming ligand, and varies only slightly with spectator ligands of similar steric demand but differing electronic influence.

This suggests:
That the rate determining step is dissociative.
That the rate determining step is associative.
That electronic effects are of no importance in the mechanism.
That all octahedral complexes react at the same rate.
That rates are not related to mechanisms.

item.title: 012 Inor1buk-Q2 Which of the following is a correct statement about Lewis

material.mattext: Which of the following is a correct statement about Lewis acids and bases?
A Lewis acid is an electron pair acceptor and a Lewis base is an electron pair donor.
A Lewis acid is a proton donor and a Lewis base is a proton acceptor.
A Lewis acid and a Lewis base both accept electron pairs.
A Lewis acid and a Lewis base both donate protons.
A Lewis acid is both a proton donor and an electron donor.
Lewis acids and bases are defined by electron pair acceptance and donation.
Lewis acids and bases are defined by electron pair acceptance and donation.
Lewis acids and bases are defined by electron pair acceptance and donation.
Lewis acids and bases are defined by electron pair acceptance and donation.

item.title: 013 Inor1cuk-Q2 Which of the following groups of organometallic compounds

material.mattext: Which of the following groups of organometallic compounds are all electron deficient (or involve multicentre orbitals)?
Alkyls of the lithium and beryllium groups.
Alkyls of boron and silicon.
Alkyls of the transition metals.
The organic compounds of mercury.
Tetraalkyls of Ti, Zr and Hf.

Electron deficiency relates pairs of bonding electrons to pairs of directly bonded atoms. Thus electron poor compounds [e.g. Ti tetraalkyls, having fewer than 18 valence electrons] are not electron deficient.

Electron deficiency relates pairs of bonding electrons to pairs of directly bonded atoms. Thus electron poor compounds [e.g. Ti tetraalkyls, having fewer than 18 valence electrons] are not electron deficient.

Electron deficiency relates pairs of bonding electrons to pairs of directly bonded atoms. Thus electron poor compounds [e.g. Ti tetraalkyls, having fewer than 18 valence electrons] are not electron deficient.

Electron deficiency relates pairs of bonding electrons to pairs of directly bonded atoms. Thus electron poor compounds [e.g. Ti tetraalkyls, having fewer than 18 valence electrons] are not electron deficient.

item.title: 014 Inor1duk-Q2 The common orthorhombic form of elemental sulphur

material.mattext: The common orthorhombic form of elemental sulphur has a structure consisting of:
Crown-like 8-membered rings.
Planar 6-membered rings.
Puckered 5-membered rings.
Three-dimensional cages.
Cross-linked polymers.

item.title: 015 Inor1euk-Q2 With which group of functions is iron associated

material.mattext: With which group of functions is iron associated in biological systems?
Storage and transport of oxygen, redox reactions.
Bone formation and repair.
Protein synthesis and hydrolysis.
Molecular rearrangement reactions.
Synthesis of fatty acids and vitamins.
Iron is at the active site in myoglobin [O2 storage], haemoglobin [O2 transport] and in the electron transport chain.
Iron is at the active site in myoglobin [O2 storage], haemoglobin [O2 transport] and in the electron transport chain.
Iron is at the active site in myoglobin [O2 storage], haemoglobin [O2 transport] and in the electron transport chain.
Iron is at the active site in myoglobin [O2 storage], haemoglobin [O2 transport] and in the electron transport chain.

item.title: 016 Inor20uk-Q2 For some dioxygen species the O-O bond lengths

material.mattext:
For some dioxygen species the O-O bond lengths are:

112 pm ; 121 pm ; 126 pm ; 149 pm

In which of the following orders are the distances as given ?
O2+ , O2 , O2- , O22-
O22- , O2- , O2 , O2+
O2 , O2- , O22- , O2+
O2+ , O22- , O2- , O2
O2- , O22- , O2+ , O2
The highest occupied molecular orbital is antibonding, so removal of an electron shortens the distance by strengthening the bond. All additions of electrons to O2 further lengthen the bond.
The highest occupied molecular orbital is antibonding, so removal of an electron shortens the distance by strengthening the bond. All additions of electrons to O2 further lengthen the bond.
The highest occupied molecular orbital is antibonding, so removal of an electron shortens the distance by strengthening the bond. All additions of electrons to O2 further lengthen the bond.
The highest occupied molecular orbital is antibonding, so removal of an electron shortens the distance by strengthening the bond. All additions of electrons to O2 further lengthen the bond.

item.title: 017 Inor24uk-Q2 How many isomeric species of all types

material.mattext:
How many isomeric species of all types can be made for an octahedral chromium species of the formula

[Cr(hfacac)3-n(acac)n]

in which "acac" is the ligand MeCOCH2COMe, and "hfacac" is CF3COCH2COCF3 ?
</CENTER>
4
5
6
7
8
Species exist for n = 0, 1, 2, and 3. Each species has an enantiomer.
Species exist for n = 0, 1, 2, and 3. Each species has an enantiomer.
Species exist for n = 0, 1, 2, and 3. Each species has an enantiomer.
Species exist for n = 0, 1, 2, and 3. Each species has an enantiomer.

item.title: 018 Inor25uk-Q2 The heats of dissociation of amine adducts of trimethyl

material.mattext:
The heats of dissociation of amine adducts of trimethyl boron [BMe3] with the following amines are given as:

Me3N 73.6 ; Me2NH 80.7 ; MeNH2 73.6 ; NH3 57.5 kJ.mol-1

These values are best rationalised as which of the following?
A combination of steric and electronic effects.
Mainly steric in origin.
Mainly electronic (inductive) in origin.
Due to hybridisation changes on B.
Due to resonance effects.
Inductively more methyls strengthen the bond, but sterically they weaken it around the small B atom. The overall picture is a net result.
Inductively more methyls strengthen the bond, but sterically they weaken it around the small B atom. The overall picture is a net result.
Inductively more methyls strengthen the bond, but sterically they weaken it around the small B atom. The overall picture is a net result.
Inductively more methyls strengthen the bond, but sterically they weaken it around the small B atom. The overall picture is a net result.

item.title: 019 Inor26uk-Q2 In the 119Sn NMR spectrum, SnCl4 has a shift

material.mattext:
In the 119Sn NMR spectrum, SnCl4 has a shift of 150 ppm, and SnBr4 has a shift of 638 ppm, relative to tetramethyltin. When the two are mixed the NMR shows peaks at the following positions, with the intensities indicated in brackets:

150 (1) ; 265 (4) ; 387 (6) ; 509 (4) ; 635 (1)

The explanation is:
Statistical formation of exchanged species SnBrnCl4-n by redistribution.
Reaction with the solvent.
Partial hydrolysis due to impurities in the mixture.
Formation of complex cluster molecules.
Formation of donor-acceptor complexes between the species.
Redistribution of Cl & Br between the tin atoms. This is common for main group elements. The clue is intensities which follow the coefficients of the Pascal triangle {statistical weightings}.
Redistribution of Cl & Br between the tin atoms. This is common for main group elements. The clue is intensities which follow the coefficients of the Pascal triangle {statistical weightings}.
Redistribution of Cl & Br between the tin atoms. This is common for main group elements. The clue is intensities which follow the coefficients of the Pascal triangle {statistical weightings}.
Redistribution of Cl & Br between the tin atoms. This is common for main group elements. The clue is intensities which follow the coefficients of the Pascal triangle {statistical weightings}.

item.title: 020 Inor27uk-Q2 Which of the following statements about thionyl chloride

material.mattext: Which of the following statements about thionyl chloride SOCl2 are true?
It can be prepared from SO2 and PCl5.
It hydrolyses readily to HCl and SO2.
It is a useful reagent for dehydrating metal salts.
The S-O bond has double bond character.
It is both a Lewis acid and a Lewis base.
All statements are correct.

item.title: 021 Inor28uk-Q3 The structures of the species [Ni(CN)4]2-

material.mattext: The structures of the species [Ni(CN)4]2-, [NiCl4]2-, and [Ni(CO)4] are respectively:
Square planar, tetrahedral, tetrahedral.
Tetrahedral, square planar, tetrahedral.
Tetrahedral, tetrahedral, square planar.
Square planar, octahedral, tetrahedral.
Tetrahedral, octahedral, square planar.

The strong-field ligand, CN-, enforces square planar geometry on the d8 ion, which avoids occupancy of the highest energy metal orbital. The others are tetrahedral as expected. Octahedral describes 6-coordinate geometry.

The strong-field ligand, CN-, enforces square planar geometry on the d8 ion, which avoids occupancy of the highest energy metal orbital. The others are tetrahedral as expected. Octahedral describes 6-coordinate geometry.

The strong-field ligand, CN-, enforces square planar geometry on the d8 ion, which avoids occupancy of the highest energy metal orbital. The others are tetrahedral as expected. Octahedral describes 6-coordinate geometry.

The strong-field ligand, CN-, enforces square planar geometry on the d8 ion, which avoids occupancy of the highest energy metal orbital. The others are tetrahedral as expected. Octahedral describes 6-coordinate geometry.

item.title: 022 Inor29uk-Q1 Which of the following statements about the two complexes

material.mattext:
Which of the following statements about the two complexes
[Co(en)(OH2)4]2+ (A) , and [Co(NH3)2(OH2)4]2+ (B) , is true ?

(en = H2NCH2CH2NH2)
A is more stable due to the chelate effect which is entropic in origin.
B is more stable because ammonia binds more strongly than ethylenediamine.
They have very similar stabilities as the nature of the bonds is very similar in both complexes.
We cannot say because it depends on the stereochemistry of the complexes.
A is more stable because the bond enthalpies are significantly higher.

There is little difference between bond strengths (enthalpies), but the bidentate ligand binds with displacement of two monodentate ligands, contributing to increased entropy. Comparison of formation constants is complicated by dimensional difficulties, but the origin of the effect is genuinely entropic.

There is little difference between bond strengths (enthalpies), but the bidentate ligand binds with displacement of two monodentate ligands, contributing to increased entropy. Comparison of formation constants is complicated by dimensional difficulties, but the origin of the effect is genuinely entropic.

There is little difference between bond strengths (enthalpies), but the bidentate ligand binds with displacement of two monodentate ligands, contributing to increased entropy. Comparison of formation constants is complicated by dimensional difficulties, but the origin of the effect is genuinely entropic.

There is little difference between bond strengths (enthalpies), but the bidentate ligand binds with displacement of two monodentate ligands, contributing to increased entropy. Comparison of formation constants is complicated by dimensional difficulties, but the origin of the effect is genuinely entropic.

item.title: 023 Inor2auk-Q2 For the reaction: trans-[Co(LL)2Cl2]

material.mattext:
For the reaction:
trans-[Co(LL)2Cl2]+  +  H2O  â  [Co(LL)2(H2O)Cl]2+  +  Cl-

the rate increases in the series:

LL = H2N(CH2)2NH2 < H2NCH2CHMeNH2 < H2NCH2CMe2NH2 < H2N(CMe2)2NH2

This is because:
The reaction is dissociative and favoured by increasing bulk.
The reaction is associative and favoured by methyl groups.
The methyl groups destabilise the starting material.
The geometry of the complexes changes across the series.
The chloride destabilises the starting material.
Thermodynamic difference and effects are minimal. The increasing bulk of the ligand favours the dissociation of Cl- and such processes are typical of substitutions at octahedral metal centres.
Thermodynamic difference and effects are minimal. The increasing bulk of the ligand favours the dissociation of Cl- and such processes are typical of substitutions at octahedral metal centres.
Thermodynamic difference and effects are minimal. The increasing bulk of the ligand favours the dissociation of Cl- and such processes are typical of substitutions at octahedral metal centres.
Thermodynamic difference and effects are minimal. The increasing bulk of the ligand favours the dissociation of Cl- and such processes are typical of substitutions at octahedral metal centres.

item.title: 024 Inor2cuk-Q2 Which of the following statements characterise the complex

material.mattext:
Which of the following statements characterise the complex

[Fe(h-C4H4)(CO)3]?
(C4H4 = cyclobutadiene).
It is a stable, 18-electron species, which liberates cyclobutadiene on oxidation by Ce(IV).
It cannot be obtained because of the instability of cyclobutadiene.
It has been prepared but is a rare example of a 20-electron Fe compound.
It can be obtained, but only as a reactive cationic salt.
The 18-electron configuration renders it unreactive to attack by either nucleophiles, electrophiles or oxidants.
The unstable ring is stabilised by coordination. Oxidation releases cyclobutadiene, which is highly reactive.
The unstable ring is stabilised by coordination. Oxidation releases cyclobutadiene, which is highly reactive.
The unstable ring is stabilised by coordination. Oxidation releases cyclobutadiene, which is highly reactive.
The unstable ring is stabilised by coordination. Oxidation releases cyclobutadiene, which is highly reactive.

item.title: 025 Inor2duk-Q2 Which of the following statements is true ?

material.mattext: Which of the following statements is true?
Silicates are formed from the fundamental SiO44- unit, but may involve sharing of 0, 1, 2, 3 or 4 "O" atoms between units.
Different silicates are based on different fundamental SiOn species.
The SiO4 unit is tetrahedral in silicates.
The only silicates which are stable are aluminosilicates which also contain aluminium.
Silicates with a planar arrangement, such as the micas, have a trigonal planar SiO33- unit.
It is the sharing of oxygen atoms between the SiO4 units which give different silicates the different overall stoichiometries. The individual units are tettrahedral.

item.title: 026 Inor30uk-Q2 The term symbol for the electronic ground state

material.mattext: The term symbol for the electronic ground state of dihydrogen H2 is:
</CENTER>
1Î£g
3Î£g
1Îg
3Î u
1Î£u

Singlet, with no unpaired electrons, symmetrical with respect to the centre of symmetry [g], sigma, no angular momentum about the bond axis (or equivalently, no change in the sign of the wavefunction).

Singlet, with no unpaired electrons, symmetrical with respect to the centre of symmetry [g], sigma, no angular momentum about the bond axis (or equivalently, no change in the sign of the wavefunction).

Singlet, with no unpaired electrons, symmetrical with respect to the centre of symmetry [g], sigma, no angular momentum about the bond axis (or equivalently, no change in the sign of the wavefunction).

Singlet, with no unpaired electrons, symmetrical with respect to the centre of symmetry [g], sigma, no angular momentum about the bond axis (or equivalently, no change in the sign of the wavefunction).

item.title: 027 Inor38uk-Q2 For the molecules [Mo2(OOCMe)4]

material.mattext: For the molecules [Mo2(OOCMe)4] , [W2Cl4(PEt3)4] and[Mo2(OBut)6(μ-CO)] the metal-metal bond orders and oxidation states are respectively:
4,4,2 and II, II, III
3,3,2 and III, III, II
2,2,0 and IV, IV, V
4,4,2 and II, IV, III
0,0,2 and V, V, III
Mo & W have 6 valence electrons; acetate, butoxide and chloride are 1-electron ligands. CO & PEt3 are 2-electron ligands. The bridging CO should be taken to contribute 1 electron to each metal.
Mo & W have 6 valence electrons; acetate, butoxide and chloride are 1-electron ligands. CO & PEt3 are 2-electron ligands. The bridging CO should be taken to contribute 1 electron to each metal.
Mo & W have 6 valence electrons; acetate, butoxide and chloride are 1-electron ligands. CO & PEt3 are 2-electron ligands. The bridging CO should be taken to contribute 1 electron to each metal.
Mo & W have 6 valence electrons; acetate, butoxide and chloride are 1-electron ligands. CO & PEt3 are 2-electron ligands. The bridging CO should be taken to contribute 1 electron to each metal.

item.title: 028 Inor39uk-Q2 Which of the following reaction sequences is correct

material.mattext:
Which of the following reaction sequences is correct for the synthesis of

cis-[PtCl2(NH3)2]     [A]?
[Pt(NH3)4]2+ + HCl  â  [PtCl(NH3)3]+  â  (+HCl)  â  [A]
[PtCl4]2- + NH3  â  [PtCl3(NH3)]- 3)  â  [A]
PtCl2 + 2NH3  â  [A]
[Pt(NH3)2]2+ + 2HCl  â  [A]
Pt + 2NH3 + Cl2  â  [A]

The sequence is determined by the Trans effects of the ligands. Cl has a higher trans-effect, and so the ligand trans to Cl is lost each time; in (2) it is one of two mutually trans Cl ligands which is lost. Reaction (1) will therefore give the trans-isomer. The other reactions are not feasible.

The sequence is determined by the Trans effects of the ligands. Cl has a higher trans-effect, and so the ligand trans to Cl is lost each time; in (2) it is one of two mutually trans Cl ligands which is lost. Reaction (1) will therefore give the trans-isomer. The other reactions are not feasible.

The sequence is determined by the Trans effects of the ligands. Cl has a higher trans-effect, and so the ligand trans to Cl is lost each time; in (2) it is one of two mutually trans Cl ligands which is lost. Reaction (1) will therefore give the trans-isomer. The other reactions are not feasible.

The sequence is determined by the Trans effects of the ligands. Cl has a higher trans-effect, and so the ligand trans to Cl is lost each time; in (2) it is one of two mutually trans Cl ligands which is lost. Reaction (1) will therefore give the trans-isomer. The other reactions are not feasible.

item.title: 029 Inor3euk-Q2 Which of the following statements about the metalloenzyme

material.mattext: Which of the following statements about the metalloenzyme, carbonic anhydrase, are true?
It contains Zn2+ coordinated by three histidine residues.
It catalyses both the hydration of CO2 and it's reverse.
It operates only to hydrate CO2.
Its direction of reaction is pH dependent.
Its function is to ensure rapid equilibration of CO2 with HCO3-.

item.title: 030 Inor3fuk-Q2 N2F4 is a highly reactive gas

material.mattext:
N2F4 is a highly reactive gas, for example, it abstracts H from thiols. The gas has an electronic absorption at 260 nm which, at constant temperature, is inversely proportional to the square root of the pressure [Âµ  1/âP].

This is because:
The compound dissociates into NF2 radicals.
It reacts with the walls of the vessel.
It dimerises.
It polymerises.
It decomposes to N2 and 2F2.
Pressure brings the radicals closer together and so suppresses the dissociation.
Pressure brings the radicals closer together and so suppresses the dissociation.
Pressure brings the radicals closer together and so suppresses the dissociation.
Pressure brings the radicals closer together and so suppresses the dissociation.
